timeline.message:
Respect jdk.tls.client.enableSessionTicketExtension and jdk.tls.server.enableSessionTicketExtension when using native SSL impl

Motivation:

We should respect jdk.tls.client.enableSessionTicketExtension and jdk.tls.server.enableSessionTicketExtension when using the native SSL implementation as well to make the usage of it easier and more consistent. These properties were introduced by JDK13:

https://seanjmullan.org/blog/2019/08/05/jdk13

Modifications:

Check if the properties are set to true and if so enable tickets

Result:

Easier to enable tickets and be more consistent

timeline.bodyText:
FYI: in JDK provider these system properties control only RFC 5077 (TLS Session Resumption Without Server-Side State) for TLSv1.2, but have no effect for TLSv1.3 its PreShaked Keys.
OpenSSL provider (BoringSSL as well) behaves differently. It uses SSL_OP_NO_TICKET to control tickets for both TLSv1.2 and TLSv1.3 [2].
Because we anyway set SSL_OP_NO_TICKET by default for OpenSSL provider, it's not an issue.
[1] https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/11/security/java-secure-socket-extension-jsse-reference-guide.html#GUID-64D7EAF6-D2EE-4719-8616-25E2829CF810
[2] https://github.com/google/boringssl/blob/3e4dfbb2f81493e1f25b3ce83fee3ed999373a6c/ssl/tls13_server.cc#L106
timeline.author: idelpivnitskiy

replies.bodyText: Yeah I think this is ok for now...

timeline.bodyText:
FYI: JDK provider also has jdk.tls.server.sessionTicketTimeout option (default to 24 hours) [1], but IIUC BoringSSL does not provide API to change default rotation interval and always uses 48 hours [2].
[1] https://docs.oracle.com/en/java/javase/11/security/java-secure-socket-extension-jsse-reference-guide.html#GUID-A41282C3-19A3-400A-A40F-86F4DA22ABA9
[2] https://commondatastorage.googleapis.com/chromium-boringssl-docs/ssl.h.html#SSL_DEFAULT_TICKET_KEY_ROTATION_INTERVAL
timeline.author: idelpivnitskiy

replies.bodyText: yep there is no API To change this in BoringSSL.
